nodes.name: Jeffrey Epstein
nodes.description: Financier and convicted sex offender. Arrested in 2019 on federal charges of sex trafficking minors, died in custody. Previously convicted in 2008 Florida case.

nodes.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
nodes.description: British socialite, daughter of Robert Maxwell. Convicted in 2021 of sex trafficking and conspiracy for her role in recruiting and grooming victims for Jeffrey Epstein.

nodes.name: Virginia Giuffre
nodes.description: Victim and accuser. Testified that she was trafficked by Epstein and Maxwell starting at age 16. Key witness in Maxwell trial and plaintiff in civil suits.

nodes.name: Leslie Wexner
nodes.description: Billionaire founder of L Brands (Victoria's Secret, Bath & Body Works). Epstein served as his financial manager from ~1988-2007, with unusual access to finances and property.

nodes.name: Leon Black
nodes.description: Billionaire co-founder of Apollo Global Management. Paid Epstein $158 million for advisory services between 2012-2017, after Epstein's 2008 conviction.

nodes.name: Bill Gates
nodes.description: Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist. Met with Epstein multiple times between 2011-2014, after Epstein's 2008 conviction, reportedly discussing philanthropy.

nodes.name: Prince Andrew
nodes.description: Duke of York, son of Queen Elizabeth II. Admitted friendship with Epstein in 2019 BBC interview. Settled civil suit with Virginia Giuffre in 2022.

nodes.name: Sarah Kellen
nodes.description: Epstein assistant. Named as potential co-conspirator in 2008 non-prosecution agreement. Identified in indictments as helping schedule victims.

nodes.name: Lesley Groff
nodes.description: Epstein executive assistant. Named as potential co-conspirator in 2008 non-prosecution agreement.

nodes.name: Juan Alessi
nodes.description: Former house manager at Epstein's Palm Beach estate. Testified at Maxwell trial about household operations and visitors.

nodes.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
nodes.description: French modeling agent. Founded MC2 Model Management with Epstein's financial backing. Found dead in Paris prison in February 2022 while awaiting trial.

nodes.name: Alan Dershowitz
nodes.description: Harvard Law professor emeritus. Represented Epstein in 2008 case and helped negotiate non-prosecution agreement. Named in Giuffre allegations, which he denies.

nodes.name: Bradley Edwards
nodes.description: Victims' rights attorney who represented multiple Epstein accusers. Author of 'Relentless Pursuit' documenting his legal fight.

nodes.name: Joi Ito
nodes.description: Former director of MIT Media Lab. Resigned in 2019 after revelations that he concealed extent of Epstein donations to the lab.

nodes.name: Bill Clinton
nodes.description: 42nd President of the United States. Flight logs show multiple trips on Epstein's aircraft. Clinton has denied knowledge of any crimes.

nodes.name: Donald Trump
nodes.description: 45th President of the United States. Publicly praised Epstein in 2002; later claimed to have banned him from Mar-a-Lago.

nodes.name: Apollo Global Management
nodes.description: Private equity firm co-founded by Leon Black. One of the world's largest alternative investment managers.

nodes.name: L Brands
nodes.description: Retail company founded by Leslie Wexner. Parent company of Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works.

nodes.name: MC2 Model Management
nodes.description: Modeling agency founded by Jean-Luc Brunel with financial backing from Jeffrey Epstein.

nodes.name: MIT Media Lab
nodes.description: Research laboratory at MIT. Received over $7.5 million in Epstein donations, often anonymized at Epstein's request.

nodes.name: TerraMar Project
nodes.description: Ocean conservation nonprofit founded by Ghislaine Maxwell in 2012. Dissolved shortly after Epstein's 2019 arrest.

nodes.name: Clinton Foundation
nodes.description: Philanthropic organization founded by Bill Clinton in 2001.

nodes.name: JPMorgan Chase
nodes.description: Major bank that maintained Epstein as client from 1998-2013. Settled victims' lawsuit for $290 million in 2023.

nodes.name: Deutsche Bank
nodes.description: German bank that became Epstein's primary bank after JPMorgan. Settled for $75 million in 2021.

nodes.name: Barclays
nodes.description: British bank. CEO Jes Staley resigned in 2021 over investigation into his Epstein relationship.

nodes.name: Jes Staley
nodes.description: Former JPMorgan executive who managed Epstein's account. Later CEO of Barclays; resigned in 2021 over Epstein probe.

nodes.name: Courtney Wild
nodes.description: Victim and advocate. Began being abused at age 14; became prominent voice seeking justice and opposing 2008 plea deal.

nodes.name: Sarah Ransome
nodes.description: Victim who provided detailed declaration about abuse on Little St. James island. Advocate for survivors.

nodes.name: Annie Farmer
nodes.description: Victim who testified at Maxwell trial. Was 16 when first abused. Sister of Maria Farmer.

nodes.name: Maria Farmer
nodes.description: Victim and artist. One of first to report Epstein to FBI in 1996. Sister of Annie Farmer.

nodes.name: Alexander Acosta
nodes.description: Former U.S. Attorney who approved controversial 2008 non-prosecution agreement. Later Secretary of Labor; resigned in 2019.

nodes.name: Kenneth Starr
nodes.description: Former federal judge and special prosecutor. Part of Epstein's defense team in 2008 case. Deceased 2022.

nodes.name: Roy Black
nodes.description: Prominent Miami defense attorney. Member of Epstein's 2008 legal team.

nodes.name: Victoria's Secret
nodes.description: Lingerie retailer founded by Leslie Wexner through L Brands. Epstein reportedly used brand to recruit.

nodes.name: 9 East 71st Street
nodes.description: Manhattan mansion transferred from Wexner to Epstein for $0. One of largest private homes in NYC.

nodes.name: Martin Nowak
nodes.description: Harvard professor of Biology and Mathematics. Received Epstein funding for Program for Evolutionary Dynamics.

nodes.name: George Church
nodes.description: Harvard geneticist. Met with Epstein; publicly apologized. Pioneer in genomics and synthetic biology.

nodes.name: Larry Summers
nodes.description: Former Harvard president (2001-2006) and Treasury Secretary. Flew on Epstein's plane.

nodes.name: Seth Lloyd
nodes.description: MIT professor of Mechanical Engineering. Received $225,000 from Epstein; placed on administrative leave.

nodes.name: Marvin Minsky
nodes.description: AI pioneer and MIT professor. Co-founder of MIT AI Lab. Named in Giuffre deposition. Deceased 2016.

nodes.name: MIT
nodes.description: Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Received substantial Epstein donations through multiple channels.

nodes.name: Harvard University
nodes.description: University that received millions in Epstein donations. Conducted internal review of gift policies.

nodes.name: Harvard Medical School
nodes.description: Medical school of Harvard University where George Church is professor.

nodes.name: Sarah Ferguson
nodes.description: Duchess of York, former wife of Prince Andrew. Epstein reportedly paid off her debts.

nodes.name: Chris Tucker
nodes.description: Actor and comedian. Appeared on Epstein flight logs. Denies knowledge of any wrongdoing.

nodes.name: Kevin Spacey
nodes.description: Actor. Appeared on Epstein flight logs on trip with Bill Clinton.

nodes.name: Naomi Campbell
nodes.description: Supermodel. Name appeared in Epstein's contact book. No allegations of wrongdoing.

nodes.name: Vicky Ward
nodes.description: Journalist who wrote 2003 Vanity Fair profile of Epstein. Claims victim accounts were cut from article.

nodes.name: Julie K. Brown
nodes.description: Miami Herald investigative reporter. Her 'Perversion of Justice' series reignited the Epstein case in 2018.

nodes.name: Glenn Dubin
nodes.description: Hedge fund manager and Highbridge Capital co-founder. Named in Giuffre deposition; denies all allegations.

nodes.name: Highbridge Capital Management
nodes.description: Hedge fund co-founded by Glenn Dubin.

nodes.name: Apollo Management
nodes.description: Alternative asset management firm. Sister entity of Apollo Global Management.

nodes.name: Blackstone Group
nodes.description: Global alternative asset management firm co-founded by Stephen Schwarzman and Pete Peterson in 1985.

nodes.name: Cascade Investment
nodes.description: Private investment and holding company of Bill Gates, managing his personal fortune.

nodes.name: Affinity Partners
nodes.description: Private equity firm founded by Jared Kushner in 2021. Received $2 billion from Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund.

nodes.name: Kushner Companies
nodes.description: Real estate development company founded by Charles Kushner. Managed by Jared Kushner before his White House role.

nodes.name: Cambridge Analytica
nodes.description: Political consulting firm funded by Robert Mercer. Infamous for Facebook data harvesting scandal. Dissolved 2018.

nodes.name: Breitbart News
nodes.description: Far-right news website. Steve Bannon served as executive chairman. Funded by Mercer family.

nodes.name: Observer Media
nodes.description: Media company formerly owned by Jared Kushner, publisher of the New York Observer.

nodes.name: Mirror Group Newspapers
nodes.description: British newspaper group owned by Robert Maxwell. Included Daily Mirror. Maxwell raided pension funds.

nodes.name: Maxwell Communications Corporation
nodes.description: Publishing conglomerate built by Robert Maxwell. Collapsed after his death, revealing massive fraud.

nodes.name: Microsoft
nodes.description: Technology company co-founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen in 1975. World's largest software maker.

nodes.name: Trump Organization
nodes.description: Conglomerate of approximately 500 business entities owned by Donald Trump. Convicted of tax fraud in 2022.

nodes.name: Trump Entertainment Resorts
nodes.description: Casino and resort company. Filed for bankruptcy multiple times. Eventually sold to Carl Icahn.

nodes.name: Trump Hotels
nodes.description: Hotel management company subsidiary of Trump Organization.

nodes.name: Ivanka Trump Brand
nodes.description: Fashion and lifestyle brand owned by Ivanka Trump. Closed in 2018.

nodes.name: J. Epstein & Co.
nodes.description: Financial management firm founded by Jeffrey Epstein. Primary vehicle for his financial advisory business.

nodes.name: Southern Trust Company
nodes.description: Financial services company associated with Epstein's U.S. Virgin Islands operations.

nodes.name: Bath & Body Works
nodes.description: Personal care retailer, formerly part of L Brands. Spun off in 2021.

nodes.name: Wexner Foundation
nodes.description: Philanthropic foundation established by Les and Abigail Wexner.

nodes.name: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
nodes.description: Largest private charitable foundation in the world. Founded by Bill and Melinda Gates in 2000.

nodes.name: Museum of Modern Art
nodes.description: Art museum in Manhattan. Leon Black served as chairman of the board.

nodes.name: Schwarzman Scholars
nodes.description: International scholarship program at Tsinghua University founded by Stephen Schwarzman.

nodes.name: Cohen & Gresser
nodes.description: Law firm. Christian Everdell was partner; represented Ghislaine Maxwell.

nodes.name: Haddon, Morgan and Foreman
nodes.description: Colorado law firm. Laura Menninger and Jeffrey Pagliuca represented Maxwell at trial.

nodes.name: Boies Schiller Flexner
nodes.description: Law firm. David Boies is chairman; represented Virginia Giuffre in various proceedings.

nodes.name: U.S. Attorney SDNY
nodes.description: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. Prosecuted Maxwell case.

nodes.name: Pitch@Palace
nodes.description: Entrepreneurship initiative founded by Prince Andrew. Suspended 2019 following Epstein scandal.

nodes.name: Stephen Schwarzman
nodes.description: Co-founder, chairman, and CEO of Blackstone Group. One of world's wealthiest individuals.

nodes.name: Pete Peterson
nodes.description: Blackstone co-founder. Former U.S. Secretary of Commerce. Deceased 2018.

nodes.name: Tony James
nodes.description: Former president and COO of Blackstone Group.

nodes.name: Jon Gray
nodes.description: President and COO of Blackstone Group. Succeeded Tony James.

nodes.name: Marc Rowan
nodes.description: Co-founder of Apollo Global Management. Became CEO after Leon Black stepped down.

nodes.name: Josh Harris
nodes.description: Co-founder of Apollo Global Management. Also owns Philadelphia 76ers and New Jersey Devils.

nodes.name: Tony Ressler
nodes.description: Co-founder of Apollo Global Management. Later founded Ares Management.

nodes.name: Warren Buffett
nodes.description: Chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway. Close associate of Bill Gates.

nodes.name: Paul Allen
nodes.description: Microsoft co-founder with Bill Gates. Philanthropist. Deceased 2018.

nodes.name: Melinda Gates
nodes.description: Philanthropist and former wife of Bill Gates. Co-chair of Gates Foundation until divorce in 2021.

nodes.name: Robert Mercer
nodes.description: Hedge fund manager at Renaissance Technologies. Major Republican donor. Funded Cambridge Analytica.

nodes.name: Rebekah Mercer
nodes.description: Daughter of Robert Mercer. Conservative activist. Sat on Breitbart board.

nodes.name: Jared Kushner
nodes.description: Real estate developer. Married to Ivanka Trump. Senior Advisor in Trump White House. Founded Affinity Partners.

nodes.name: Ivanka Trump
nodes.description: Daughter of Donald Trump. Executive VP of Trump Organization. Senior Advisor in Trump White House.

nodes.name: Charles Kushner
nodes.description: Real estate developer. Father of Jared Kushner. Convicted of tax evasion, witness tampering in 2005; pardoned 2020.

nodes.name: Steve Bannon
nodes.description: Former Breitbart executive chairman and Trump chief strategist. Convicted of contempt of Congress.

nodes.name: Robert Maxwell
nodes.description: British media proprietor. Father of Ghislaine Maxwell. Died 1991 under mysterious circumstances. Revealed to have committed massive fraud.

nodes.name: Abigail Wexner
nodes.description: Wife of Leslie Wexner. Attorney and philanthropist.

nodes.name: Audrey Strauss
nodes.description: Former Acting U.S. Attorney for SDNY. Announced Maxwell indictment in July 2020.

nodes.name: Geoffrey Berman
nodes.description: Former U.S. Attorney for SDNY. Oversaw initial Epstein prosecution in 2019.

nodes.name: Christian Everdell
nodes.description: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser. Part of Maxwell defense team.

nodes.name: Bobbi Sternheim
nodes.description: Criminal defense attorney. Lead counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell at trial.

nodes.name: Laura Menninger
nodes.description: Attorney at Haddon, Morgan and Foreman. Part of Maxwell defense team.

nodes.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
nodes.description: Attorney at Haddon, Morgan and Foreman. Part of Maxwell defense team.

nodes.name: Sigrid McCawley
nodes.description: Attorney at Boies Schiller Flexner. Lead counsel for Virginia Giuffre in multiple cases.

nodes.name: David Boies
nodes.description: Chairman of Boies Schiller Flexner. Represented Virginia Giuffre and other Epstein victims.

nodes.name: Jay Lefkowitz
nodes.description: Attorney at Kirkland & Ellis. Represented Jeffrey Epstein in 2008 negotiations.

nodes.name: Bear Stearns
nodes.description: Investment bank where Epstein worked 1976-1981. Made partner despite lacking college degree. Collapsed in 2008.

nodes.name: Alan Greenberg
nodes.description: CEO of Bear Stearns 1978-1993. Hired Epstein as options trader. Later denied close relationship.

nodes.name: Towers Financial
nodes.description: Company at center of $450 million Ponzi scheme. Hoffenberg convicted; Epstein never charged despite involvement.

nodes.name: Steven Hoffenberg
nodes.description: Convicted fraudster. Sentenced to 20 years in 1997 for Towers Financial Ponzi scheme. Claimed Epstein was partner.

nodes.name: Mortimer Zuckerman
nodes.description: Real estate developer and media owner. Owner of NY Daily News (1993-2017) and U.S. News & World Report. Early Epstein client.

nodes.name: Daily News
nodes.description: New York tabloid newspaper. Owned by Mortimer Zuckerman 1993-2017.

nodes.name: U.S. News & World Report
nodes.description: American media company. Owned by Mortimer Zuckerman 1984-2010.

nodes.name: Colony Capital
nodes.description: Private equity firm founded by Tom Barrack in 1991. Now called DigitalBridge.

nodes.name: Tom Barrack
nodes.description: Founder of Colony Capital. Major Trump fundraiser. Indicted on foreign lobbying charges 2021. In Epstein's contacts.

nodes.name: John Brockman
nodes.description: Literary agent and founder of Edge Foundation. Facilitated Epstein's access to scientific elite through dinners and events.

nodes.name: Edge Foundation
nodes.description: Scientific salon founded by John Brockman. Hosted dinners where Epstein networked with scientists and academics.

nodes.name: Rockefeller University
nodes.description: Private research university in NYC. Received Epstein donations for scientific research.

nodes.name: Santa Fe Institute
nodes.description: Independent research center for complexity science. Received Epstein funding.

nodes.name: Council on Foreign Relations
nodes.description: Nonpartisan foreign policy think tank. Epstein was a member of this elite organization.

nodes.name: Stephen Hawking
nodes.description: Renowned theoretical physicist. Attended 2006 conference on Epstein's island. Deceased 2018.

nodes.name: Nathan Myhrvold
nodes.description: Former Microsoft CTO (1996-2000). Photographed with Epstein at scientific events. Founded Intellectual Ventures.

nodes.name: Elite Model Management
nodes.description: Major modeling agency founded by John Casablancas in 1972. History of abuse allegations in industry.

nodes.name: John Casablancas
nodes.description: Founder of Elite Model Management. Pioneer of supermodel era. Reputation for relationships with young models. Deceased 2013.

nodes.name: Karin Models
nodes.description: Paris modeling agency founded by Jean-Luc Brunel. Predecessor to MC2.

nodes.name: Alicia Arden
nodes.description: Model who filed police report against Epstein in 1997 after he groped her during a supposed Victoria's Secret audition. Case was not prosecuted.

nodes.name: Zorro Ranch
nodes.description: 8,000-acre ranch in Stanley, New Mexico. Site of Epstein's eugenics discussions according to NYT.

nodes.name: Little St. James
nodes.description: 70-acre private island in U.S. Virgin Islands. Known as 'Pedophile Island.' Purchased by Epstein in 1998 for $7.95M.

nodes.name: Great St. James
nodes.description: Second USVI island purchased by Epstein in 2016 for $22.5M. Adjacent to Little St. James.

nodes.name: Eva Andersson-Dubin
nodes.description: Miss Sweden 1980. Dated Epstein in mid-1980s. Married Glenn Dubin in 1994. Family maintained relationship with Epstein.

nodes.name: Pepe Fanjul
nodes.description: Cuban-American billionaire. Sugar industry magnate with brother Alfonso. Part of Epstein's Palm Beach social circle.

nodes.name: Mar-a-Lago
nodes.description: Palm Beach estate owned by Donald Trump. Epstein was a member before being banned. Virginia Giuffre was recruited there while working as spa attendant.

nodes.name: Mossad
nodes.description: Israeli intelligence agency. Multiple sources allege Robert Maxwell worked as an asset.

nodes.name: PROMIS Software
nodes.description: Case management software stolen from Inslaw Inc. Allegedly sold worldwide by Maxwell with backdoors for intelligence agencies.

nodes.name: Israel
nodes.description: State of Israel. Robert Maxwell buried on Mount of Olives with state funeral attended by PM, President, and intelligence chiefs.

nodes.name: Ehud Barak
nodes.description: Former Israeli Prime Minister and Defense Minister. Acknowledged visiting Epstein's island and Manhattan home. Chairman of Carbyne 911, which received Epstein investment.

nodes.name: Carbyne 911
nodes.description: Israeli emergency services technology company. Chaired by Ehud Barak. Received investment from Epstein-linked fund. Board included Nicole Junkermann.

nodes.name: Nicole Junkermann
nodes.description: German-British investor. Business ties to Epstein. Invested in Carbyne 911 with Barak. Served on UK NHS health technology advisory board.

nodes.name: Mega Group
nodes.description: Informal network of pro-Israel billionaire donors. Co-founded by Leslie Wexner and Charles Bronfman in 1991.

nodes.name: Charles Bronfman
nodes.description: Canadian-American businessman. Seagram heir. Co-founded Mega Group with Leslie Wexner.

nodes.name: Victor Ostrovsky
nodes.description: Former Mossad case officer. Author of 'By Way of Deception' (1990) which detailed Robert Maxwell's intelligence role.

nodes.name: Ari Ben-Menashe
nodes.description: Former Israeli intelligence officer. Author of 'Profits of War' (1992). Made claims about Maxwell and Epstein intelligence connections.

nodes.name: Harvard Law School
nodes.description: [Description pending - requires sourced research]
